TopicTitle: Landing on Eeloo with seriously underpowered lander

Articles.Content:
I have an ion-driven probe in low orbit around Eeloo. I've got almost all the orbit science, but I would really like to land it. It has about 2000 m/s left in fuel, so there is no future job it could do other than visit Jool (no need) or crash into Duna (idem).

The problem is: power.

The probe has an orbital scanner, a few experiments, a Hex core and eight 6x1 solar panels. And a 1k battery. With nothing switched on, the battery charges at 0.4 units per second. At full power, the ion engine (TWR approx 1.16 on Eeloo, apparently) causes negative charge of around 8.5 units per second. SAS would increase that a bit.

This means that from a fully charged battery, I can get about 250 m/s out of the thing at full thrust. Or I can run the ion engine indefinitely at about 5% thrust, but only in full sunlight.

So the question is: is there any possible way to land on Eeloo? A constant-altitude burn would help, and I can get the last 200 m/s with a TWR of 1.16, but is it actually possible to start one with a TWR of 0.06?

Yah, you're basically hosed.

You only get one load of power.  If you're charging at 0.4/sec in the best case, that means it takes over 40 minutes of zero usage to recharge.  So, you've got 250 m/s and that's that.  Orbital velocity on Eeloo is around 500 m/s; you simply have no way to kill that.

Put another way:  Eeloo's surface gravity is 1.69 m/s2.  Let's imagine you don't have any horizontal component at all to worry about, and are descending straight down, and that you're making a perfect suicide burn that puts you at 0 m/s at the moment you touch the surface.  You've mentioned a TWR of 1.16 on Eeloo, so your deceleration while descending would be 1.69 * (1.16-1) = 0.27 m/s2.  You have a maximum thrust time of 1000 / 8.5 = 118 seconds.  Combine that with your deceleration and we get 31.8 m/s.  Height at that point would be 118 * 31.8 / 2 = 1877 m.

So:  If you start, fully charged, at an altitude of 1877 m while descending at 31.8 m/s, then you have just barely enough juice to land.

You simply can't do any better than that.

So, the question is:  Given that you're orbiting at 500 m/s, is there some way to put you less than 2 km above the surface while traveling only 32 m/s, and have a full charge at that point?  I'd say the answer is a resounding "no."

Sorry, dude. 

BTW, for future reference:  if you're going out to Jool and beyond, solar panels really don't pull their weight-- you'd get more power-per-kilogram with an RTG.  Of course, that's only an option if you've unlocked the RTG, which is way the heck at the top of the tech tree, but it's worth bearing in mind.

Yeah, what I send to the Jool system generally has an RTG, but for my standard orbital scanner design I didn't see a good place to fit one and maintain balance, it would have vastly increased the cost and significantly increased weight, and I figured that waits between burns would be manageable - which it has been so far.
Eeloo approach had to be done in stages but it was satisfying.

I suppose I was hoping some odd strategy might let me turn a slightly eliptic orbital trajectory into a suborbital trajectory, but those numbers don't seem to leave any possibility whatsoever. With 10x the solar panels it might have been doable ; )

1 hour ago, Plusck said:

I suppose I was hoping some odd strategy might let me turn a slightly eliptic orbital trajectory into a suborbital trajectory, but those numbers don't seem to leave any possibility whatsoever. With 10x the solar panels it might have been doable ; )

Except that then your TWR would be lower than 1.16.  That's really your problem there-- the gravity losses are just killing you.  For example, in that example where I went through the numbers:  you're spending 250 m/s of dV just to kill 32 m/s of vertical velocity.  Hideously inefficient.

You'd probably do better just increasing the battery capacity, and making up for it by having fewer solar panels to save mass... though not sure if that would be enough.  The 1x6 panels are 17.5 kg or 25 kg apiece, depending on whether you have the retractable ones; whereas an additional 1000EC battery is 50 kg.  So you could triple your battery storage and make up for the mass by losing 4-6 of the solar panels.

In any case, moral of the story:  ion drives really don't have much muscle  at Eeloo.
